chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected food allergy?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a diagnosis of immunoglobulin (Ig)E-mediated food allergy is suspected on the basis of reported or observed clinical features:

  • Ask about:
    • The possible causal food or foods.
    • The symptoms, frequency, speed of onset, duration, and the timing of the reaction in relation to the suspected allergen exposure. A food and symptom diary may be helpful.
    • The form in which the food has been eaten (raw, semi-cooked, cooked, or baked), and quantity of food ingested.
    • Any uneventful exposures to the suspected allergen before or after the reaction.
    • The setting of reactions (such as school or home).
    • The reproducibility of symptoms on repeated food exposure.
    • The age when symptoms started, the person's feeding history (age of complementary feeding [weaning], breast- or formula-fed), weight gain, and nutritional status.
    • Any co-factors which may increase the likelihood of a clinical reaction: age (teenager and young adults), exercise, menstruation, stress, infection; ingestion of aspirin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), or alcohol.
    • Any co-morbid atopic conditions such as asthma, eczema, or allergic rhinitis. See the CKS topics on Asthma, Eczema - atopic, and Allergic rhinitis for more information.
    • Any family history of food allergy or atopic conditions, particularly in parents and siblings.
    • Any symptom response to dietary restrictions or reintroduction of foods, and/or medications tried, such as oral antihistamines.
  • Examine the person for:
    • Nutritional status, including weight, length/height, and calculation of body mass index (BMI).
    • Any signs of a clinical reaction.
    • Any signs of co-morbid conditions such as asthma, atopic eczema, and/or allergic rhinitis.
  • Arrange for skin prick testing and/or serum-specific IgE allergy testing to the suspected food allergens and likely cross-reactive foods, depending on local referral pathways and availability.
    • See the section on Specialist referral for more information.
  • Advise the person that the following diagnostic tools are not recommended for the diagnosis of IgE-mediated food allergy:
    • Serum-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)G testing.
    • Trial food elimination diet (although this may be helpful in the diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated food allergy, under dietetic supervision).
    • Vega testing (electroacupuncture devices).
    • Applied kinesiology (muscle strength testing).
    • Hair analysis (assessing mineral content).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the assessment of a person with suspected food allergy are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (RCPCH) publication Allergy Care Pathways for Children. Food allergy [RCPCH, 2011], the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) Food allergy and anaphylaxis guidelines: managing patients with food allergy in the community [Muraro, 2014]; the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) Guidelines for the management of egg allergy [Clark, 2010] and Guideline for the diagnosis and management of peanut and tree nut allergy [Stiefel, 2017]; the International Collaboration in Asthma, Allergy and Immunology consensus document ICON: Food allergy [Burks, 2012], the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of food allergy in the United States [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in review articles on food allergy [Longo, 2013; Steele, 2014; Turnbull, 2015; Meyer, 2018] and oral allergy syndrome [Price, 2015].

Assessing symptoms and signs

  • The recommendation to consider use of a food and symptom diary is based on the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011] and expert opinion in a review article [Price, 2015].
  • The recommendation to ask about any uneventful exposures to the suspected food allergen is based on the fact that there may be a dose-dependent threshold for reactivity. It may also highlight incorrectly identified food triggers [Boyce, 2010; Steele, 2014].
  • The recommendation to assess for the presence of co-factors such as teenager and young adult age-group is based on the fact that they are at increased risk of non-fatal and fatal accidental reactions, due to increased risk-taking behaviour, failure to carry an adrenaline auto-injector, and the use of alcohol [Stiefel, 2017].
  • The recommendation to assess for the presence of atopic co-morbidities is based on the fact that a history of food allergy and persistent asthma is an indication for referral for consideration of adrenaline autoinjector therapy, as a history of severe asthma increases the risk of severe allergic reaction and anaphylaxis [Stiefel, 2017]. In addition, atopic eczema may be exacerbated by ingestion of a known food allergen [Longo, 2013].
  • The recommendation to ask about family history of atopy affecting first-degree relatives is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018].
  • The recommendations on examination are based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], and expert opinion in a review article [Meyer, 2018].

Arranging allergy testing

  • The recommendation to arrange skin prick and/or serum-specific immunoglobulin (Ig)E allergy testing is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the BSACI guidelines [Clark, 2010; Stiefel, 2017], the ICON consensus document [Burks, 2012], the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010], the RCPCH publication [RCPCH, 2011], and expert opinion in a review article [Steele, 2014].
    • The NICE clinical guideline highlights that allergy testing should only be offered if appropriate, after an allergy-focused history has been taken. In addition, it states that accurate identification of true food allergy will help to reduce the incidence of adverse reactions, and reduce unnecessary dietary exclusion of foods that are safe and should be eaten as part of a normal, healthy diet.
    • The NICE clinical guideline found low-quality evidence that skin prick testing and serum-specific IgE testing were similar in their diagnostic performance. Health economic analysis found that both tests were more cost-effective than no test.

Diagnostic tests not recommended

  • The advice that food elimination diets should not be used in the diagnosis of IgE-mediated food allergy is based on expert opinion in a review article [Turnbull, 2015]. The RCPCH publication and NICE clinical guideline note that trial elimination diets may be used in the diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated food allergy under dietitian supervision [RCPCH, 2011; NICE, 2018].
  • The NICE clinical guideline found no good-quality evidence for the use of alternative diagnostic tools in the diagnosis of suspected IgE-mediated food allergy [NICE, 2018]. This approach is supported by the NIAID guidelines [Boyce, 2010].
